head.title: Elegy VI.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 20-22.

l.emph: What shall I say, what arguments can prove
My truth, what colours can describe my love?

epigraph.bibl: Prior.22 Matthew Prior, “Celia to Damon,” in Poems on Several Occasions (1720), 34-38. Turnbull substituted “what shall I say” for Prior’s “what can I say.”

lg.l: No other maid, of all the youthful train,
However sweet to others they may be,
Shall e’er invade my constant heart again;

None shall I, Delia,33 Name of Artemis or Diana, who was allegedly born in the island of Delos. Citing Tibullus, Maurice Scêve (1510-64) and Samuel Daniel (1562-1619), Alastair Fowler argues that Delia was often used to denote purity. See Literary Names (Oxford: Oxford UP, 2012), p. 44. ever love but thee.
From thee at first the fatal arrow came,
And, to my heart, an easy passage found,
With secret joy I fed the subtile flame,
Nor knew the sad effects of such a wound.
I valu’d more one sweet endearing smile
Than all the treasure Indian mines afford,
Greater I was than if of Albion’s isle,44 Ancient name for Britain, likely derived from the Latin albus meaning "white" and thus a reference to the island's southern coast.
And wealthy cities, I were sov’reign Lord.
But ah! my charmer, little did I know
What racks and torments I should shortly prove,
Disdain, the fatal cause of all my wo,
And jealousy, the greatest bane of love.
No friend of fortune I, no wealthy swain,
Possess’d of num’rous herds and fields of corn;
For this I suffer thy unjust disdain,
Not me, but ’tis my poverty you scorn.
Yet, yet my fair, the little I could claim,
All that I could command, and call it mine,
All that I had, that instant yours became,
My heart, my life, my very soul was thine.
What task can you enjoin me to obey,
What dreadful penance urge me to sustain?
Be what it will, without the least delay,
It shall be done, your favour to obtain.
For thee, I’d brave the dangers of the storm,

And like Leander,55 In Greek mythology, Leander swam across the Hellespont every night to be with his lover, Hero. The myth was versified by Christopher Marlowe and, after Marlowe’s death, George Chapman and published as Hero and Leander in 1598. nightly swim the tide,
Gladly I’d meet its ev’ry dreadful form,
Did you appear, my wat’ry course to guide.

I’d live on Zembla’s outmost coast66 Novaya Zemlya is an archipelago in the Arctic Ocean and was, in the eighteenth century, commonly referred to by its Dutch name, Nova Zembla. In A New Geographical, Historical and Commercial Grammar (1774) William Guthrie et al. describe it and “Russian Lapland” as “most uncomfortable regions; the earth, which is covered with snow nine months in the year, being extremely barren, and every where encumbered with unwholesome marshes, uninhibited mountains, and impenetrable thickness,” p. 524. exil’d,
Where hoary winter chills the joyless year,
Where vernal suns and summer never smil’d,
Yet this were paradise if thou wert near.
But hold, fond youth, what fury moves thy mind?
What frantic pow’r constrains thee this to tell?
Already, to thy sorrow may’st thou find,
She knows of thy submission far too well.
